content.raw:
Replace this with: `beforeKickOffState(std::make_shared<BeforeKickOffState>(BeforeKickOff, this)),`

`std::make_shared` is the recommended way of allocating an object using a std::shared_ptr. It's a little bit more efficient than `new` and safer. Apply the same suggestion to the rest of `new ...`
content.html:
Replace this with: beforeKickOffState(std::make_shared<BeforeKickOffState>(BeforeKickOff, this)),

std::make_shared is the recommended way of allocating an object using a std::shared_ptr. It's a little bit more efficient than new and safer. Apply the same suggestion to the rest of new ...

content.html:
Consider using the for range loop syntax for this type of for loops:

for (auto &team : this->teams)
  {
    for (auto &agent : team->members)
    {
      agent.status = Agent::Status::RELEASED;
    }
  }

content.raw:
according to this: http://www.cprogramming.com/reference/pointers/const_pointers.html, 

const GameState *_gameState means that I cant modify _gameState, which is something that the State object needs to do. 

GameState *const _gameState means that the pointer address cant be modified, which is correct.
content.html:
according to this: http://www.cprogramming.com/reference/pointers/const_pointers.html,

const GameState *_gameState means that I cant modify _gameState, which is something that the State object needs to do.

GameState *const _gameState means that the pointer address cant be modified, which is correct.

pullrequest.title: Adding GameState class and tests to default branch

content.raw: I noticed that in your tests, you're always using `ASSERT_*` and never using `EXPECT_*`. It's nice to use `EXPECT` when the test can move on even if that condition failed, which allows us to spot several failures at once. `ASSERT` should only be used if it doesn't make sense to continue the test unless that passes. Could you update the tests to use more `EXPECT`?
content.html: I noticed that in your tests, you're always using ASSERT_* and never using EXPECT_*. It's nice to use EXPECT when the test can move on even if that condition failed, which allows us to spot several failures at once. ASSERT should only be used if it doesn't make sense to continue the test unless that passes. Could you update the tests to use more EXPECT?
